images.title: Christine Matthews / Rye Meads RSPB Nature Reserve
images.caption: Some of the inhabitants of the Rye Meads Nature Reserve, including a Heron on the walkway, plus a number of Black-Headed Gulls and other water birds.

images.title: Peter Trimming, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Kingfisher seen at Rye Meads.I'm lead to believe that this is the male. Currently incubating eggs, this bird is ringed.

images.title: Jack Hill / Rye Meads Bird Sanctuary
images.caption: Rye Meads Bird Sanctuary. This is an RSPB reserve on old, now redundant, filter beds. The rafts are provided for little terns to use as breeding platforms so have a gravel floor and shelters for the babies.

images.title: Robert Edwards / Rye House Gatehouse
images.caption: Rye House Gatehouse. This gatehouse was built in 1443 and is all that's left of the estate of Rye House that was destroyed by fire. The building was built by a Danish Lord called Sir Andrew Ogard.

images.title: © User:Colin / Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Barges on River Lee Navigation north of the reserve

images.title: Brian Johnson / Hoddesdon Clock Tower and Market
images.caption: Hoddesdon Clock Tower and Market

images.title: David Benstead / The New River, Hoddesdon
images.caption: The New River, Hoddesdon

description: This RSPB bird reserve in Hoddesdon has some nice nature trails to try. There's a number of lakes and other waterside trails along the River Lea which runs through the area. Look out for birds including herons, kingfishers, snipe, green sandpipers, shovelers, gadwalls and tufted ducks. The reserve has a car park at the southern end but the Rye House railway station is located right next to the reserve so its easy to come by public transport too. To extend the walk you could follow the River Lea north to Ware , passing more lakes around Stansted Abbotts on the way. Heading south would take you towards Nazing Mead, Clayton Hill Country Park and Waltham Abbey .
